curriculum.description: Management control focuses on the actions managers take to help ensure that the organization’s objectives and strategies are accomplished, or modified should conditions require it. Increasingly, news stories report control debacles where organizations have suffered large losses, and in some instances, even failure. Each organization must develop its own model for proactively assessing and controlling business risks. This course explores various aspects of the design and evaluation of management control systems. Among the topics discussed are: business risks assessment, beliefs and boundary systems, interactive control systems, diagnostic control systems, open-book management, the balanced (value) scorecard, and performance measures.

This course examines the role cost information can play in strategic management decisions. Use of activity-based costing (ABC) is one way of linking cost analysis to strategy. ABC systems also enable managers to focus on efficiently managing activities so that they add value for customers. Other ways that are studied in which cost analysis can help managers include capacity costing, target costing, and relating cost analysis to the theory of constraints. Mr. Peter Turney, a former professor and current CEO of Cost Technologies (an ABC consulting firm), is the instructor for the 1997-98 offering of this course. He is the author of numerous articles and books on ABC.

This course considers significant financial accounting and reporting issues, in the context of the management decisions those issues require. Students will study such classic and contemporary topics as revenue recognition, disclosure of contingencies, the quality of earnings, and the valuation of assets and liabilities – the very issues being debated daily by Congress, the SEC, auditors and boards of directors everywhere. We will look at the material with a zoom lens, most often retaining a broad focus on the business implications of a financial reporting or accounting issue. Students should see themselves as members of their firm’s executive committee — people who know the business intimately and who have a legitimate interest in how the results of the business will be reported. Several times during the course we will narrow the focus to look at an accounting issue in detail, so as to explore the process by which accounting standards are established, and how they are implemented. Some of the course looks at the same topics as first year accounting, but more comprehensively. Much of the course addresses topics which were not discussed thoroughly in the first year, such as accounting for foreign operations, pensions, financial instruments and contingencies. This is intended to round out the student’s understanding of the complete picture being communicated by a set of financial statements and the associated disclosures. The course has been designed to give the students a deeper understanding of the issues managements must consider as they confront difficult accounting and reporting questions. The objectives of the course are to help the participants visualize the implications of the decisions they confront, to articulate their objectives for the decision, and to chart a general solution, recognizing the parameters from Generally Accepted Accounting Principles which might apply. The course is also intended to provide an introduction to the analysis of financial statements through the study and interpretation of a set of “mystery” financial statements. This exercise is intended to sharpen the student’s ability to assess overall operating performance and financial condition, and to better understand what management is communicating. Grading will be based 40% on class participation, 20% on an in-class paper, and 40% on the results of a final examination. The Fall 2002 “Decisions in Financial Reporting” course will be offered by Professors Allen and Sack. The enclosed course outline is a draft based on the Spring 2002 course. The final course outline will look much like this.

The objective of this course is to help students develop a rich, conceptual understanding of our society’s accounting and financial reporting system.  Our discussion will proceed at both an intellectual and a practical level.  We will explore contemporary issues (for example, corporate governance, the role of the auditors, mergers and acquisitions, intangible assets, derivatives and stock options) and classic issues (for example, revenue recognition and valuation reserves), working to understand the issue at hand and at the same time to consider the implications of that issue for the numerous constituencies served by the financial reporting system.  We will examine the impact that the recent accounting and related business scandals have had on investor confidence and the capital markets, and we will analyze some specific examples of the fraudulent financial reporting that has occurred.  Although the primary focus of this course will be on accounting and reporting practices in the United States, we will also address the significant progress that has been made toward establishing international accounting standards. The course is designed for those students who will work with the financial reporting system on a frequent basis, whether as a member of a company’s finance function, as a member of the investment community, as a financially-oriented consultant, or as a business owner.  The people responsible for a company’s corporate finance function use the financial reporting system to help communicate the company’s value to its public constituencies.  The people in the investment community use the reporting system to help them gather information on investment opportunities and to evaluate their prospects. Some consultants use the reporting system to help their clients see the financial impact of a restructuring or reorganization.  Some entrepreneurs use the financial reporting system to help them raise the capital they need for growing their businesses.  In each case, the users of the system must understand its purpose and the logic that supports it, the exceptions to that logic that are embedded in the system, and the process by which the system’s standards are established.  The development of that understanding is one of the basic objectives of the course.  Given that challenging objective, along with the scope and the complexity of the material covered, the course will be both thought-provoking and intense.  Students taking the course will be expected to have a good conceptual and working knowledge of the financial accounting content of the first-year ACC course. Students should not sign up for this course and the 15 session elective, Decisions in Financial Reporting.  Choose one or the other. FOR WHOM THE COURSE IS INTENDED: Students interested in careers in corporate finance, corporate accounting or treasury, investment banking, commercial banking, public accounting, or management consulting.

Course will survey and analyze through a series of selected cases the tax issues encountered in structuring mergers and acquisitions including both taxable and tax-free formats. Topics covered will include comparison from both buyer and seller perspectives of advantages and disadvantages of sales (purchase) of assets vs. sale (purchase) of stock in taxable transactions; techniques in structuring tax-free reorganizations and spin-offs of corporate divisions and subsidiaries; and introduction to tax-driven aspects of business valuation in the M&A context and also in the context of the limiting the impact of federal estate tax on business entities seeking to structure succession of the business to succeeding generations.

Students seeking careers in investment banking, venture capital, private equity, corporate finance, corporate development, and management consulting will find this course appropriate. Although students pursuing these career paths do not need tax expertise, they do need to be able to evaluate critically when to call in the tax experts and to understand what the tax experts are saying. This course provides a general survey of the basic tax consequences from fundamental restructuring strategies and a framework for evaluating the priority that taxes have in these strategies. Students will be required to analyze how tax consequences affect the value of different strategies to the buyer and seller. Understanding the effect of taxes on the value of a deal for the buyer and seller prepares future financial executives and strategic advisors for making the right decisions and being effective negotiators. The course focuses on the tax consequences of restructuring strategies and their valuation implications, but it also covers the nontax advantages and disadvantages of these strategies. Most of the course covers the U.S. federal income tax issues of the restructuring of C corporations, but it also will address pass-through entities. Other topics will be taxable asset and stock acquisitions, tax-free asset and stock reorganizations, and divestitures and liquidations. The principal modes of instruction are cases, readings, articles, and exercises.

The objective of this course is to explore the financial reporting practices of companies in other countries. The course is not, however, intended to focus solely on analyzing and understanding foreign financial statements. Since reporting standards, and in fact the content of financial statements, reflect national and cultural characteristics of a country, the course emphasizes looking at the key environmental factors conditioning the financial reporting practices in the focal country.

Course covers basic tax concepts relevant in operating any business enterprise including Sole Proprietorships, Partnerships, S Corporations, and C Corporations.  Specific topics covered include coverage of individual income tax issues, analysis of after-tax return on investments, tax consequences of different financing decisions, taxation of various retirement savings plans, tax issues when forming new businesses, and tax consequences of hiring employees vs. independent contractors.

This course is about blending finance, strategy, accounting, and tax law in the analyses of high-value-added business decisions. The course is not about: tax compliance (the correct way to file tax returns), tax complexity (finding loopholes), tax minimization (beating Uncle Sam), or tax evasion (filing illegal returns). Students will learn a framework for evaluating the priority that taxes, which directly or indirectly pervade most business transactions, have in business decisions. Students will explore a variety of fundamental business issues such as forming a company, compensating employees, attracting investors, financing projects, and positioning worldwide operations. While the topics deal primarily with U.S. income taxes, the course’s conceptual framework applies irrespective of time and jurisdiction. Students seeking careers in entrepreneurship, management consulting, investment banking, venture capital, or industry, especially general management, corporate finance, or accounting, will find this course of interest. No prior knowledge of taxation is required. The principal modes of instruction are cases and articles. The final group paper enables students to tailor the course to address an area of personal interest.

Strategic costing is concerned with use of internal cost accounting information to plan and evaluate strategic operations and interactions with stakeholders of the firm. The focus is on planning and strategic decision-making by the organization and on the accounting systems that managers have to assist them in their decisions about resource allocation and performance evaluation. The course is intended as an extension of the foundational cost accounting concepts taught in Core Accounting. It is targeted for individuals who will, or who will help (e.g., as either internal or external management consultants) managers, make strategic business decisions, evaluate business units, and evaluate others (or be evaluated) through the use of cost information.  The course will address two major uses of cost accounting information: (1) to facilitate strategic managerial decision-making and (2) to influence strategic decision-makers to make decisions in the best interests of the organization owners.

GBUS 8395      Communicating Financial and Sustainability Performance: The Roles of the CFO, the Board, and Regulators This course develops expertise in stewarding responsible public disclosure to external stakeholders through an analysis of the managerial decisions that drive both financial and non-financial communications. The focus of the course is on the roles of a company’s accounting system, management and board in creating an environment where managerial decisions lead to high quality stewardship of public disclosure. This course is not about the managerial decisions required by specific generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) or about using publicly available accounting information to determine companies’ valuations. After an introduction to the regulatory requirements surrounding corporate disclosures, the course analyzes external communications of financial information through managerial decisions related to earnings guidance, pro-forma earnings, earnings restatements and crises. The course then examines managerial decision-making related to the public disclosure of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance. ESG performance spans a range of issues, including company carbon emissions, labor and human rights policies, and corporate governance structures. The course will examine the disclosure of ESG initiatives, the adoption of sustainability accounting standards, and the use of integrated reporting of financial and ESG performance. By the end of this course, students will have a broad understanding of the regulatory landscape and strategic decisions facing executives, directors and regulators regarding the disclosure of financial and nonfinancial performance to the public.

GBUS 8410 FINANCIAL STATEMENT ANALYSIS AND CORPORATE VALUATION This course uses reported accounting data that provides a foundation for the application of tools and techniques to derive the measurements that aid in corporate valuation. Students will develop an understanding of screening, forecasting, and valuation tools that aid in the analysis and exploitation of information contained in financial statements. The course includes but is not limited to topics related to the use of ratio analysis, the theory and development of cash-flow and earnings-based valuation models, identification of financial statement management, and the impact of accounting principles and assumptions on valuation. Course content will encompass three modules. The first strengthens students’ understanding of key accounting relations and how detailed ratio analysis can provide a historical perspective on firm activities. An emphasis also is placed on the role of nonfinancial information used as supplements to required accounting reports. The second builds on this foundation with an explicit focus on common valuation and earnings-forecasting techniques that include financial model building using discounted cash flow, multiples, and earnings-based valuation methods. The final module identifies the critical accounting factors that may be unique to the given firm under evaluation. These factors will include identification of and adjustment for off-balance sheet assets and liabilities, multi-national operations, and detecting earnings management. This course should appeal to those planning careers in financial management, consulting, security analysis, investment banking, or credit analysis.

This course is intended for students who want to extend their knowledge and comprehensive understanding at both the conceptual and practical level of our accounting and financial reporting system beyond the topics covered in the prerequisite elective course, Financial Reporting and Analysis. It will provide students with new opportunities to take an in-depth look at challenging contemporary financial accounting and reporting issues and practices pertaining to inventory valuations, sales-type and operating leases, accounting changes, corporate restructurings, financial contingencies, mergers and acquisitions, and market valuations. Other topics covered will include earnings management, earnings per share, earnings quality, and corporate governance. The course also examines the impact that the recent accounting and related business scandals have had on investor confidence and the capital markets, and it includes a number of examples of fraudulent financial reporting that has occurred. Although the primary focus of this course is on accounting and reporting practices in the United States, it also addresses the significant progress made in establishing international financial reporting standards.

This course is intended to provide students with an understanding of the design and use of planning and control systems to facilitate the implementation of an organization’s strategy. Many organizations have discovered that having a great strategy is not enough if the right structures and processes are not in place to implement that strategy. A major challenge facing most organizations is to design systems that allow them to drive growth and profitability without subjecting the organization to long-term risk. This course examines the design and use of planning and control systems for implementing organizational strategy and achieving growth and profit goals. The primary focus in the course is on accounting-based controls that involve the use of financial measures and tools for allocating resources, measuring performance, and regulating inter-unit activity.
Short Description	Business and the Political Economy

The project work should revolve around a well defined set of current business issues whose investigation requires some of the work to be done “in the field”.  Our aim is to conduct the work in a manner that satisfies and exceeds the professional standards of the outside world. In order to simplify administration, second-year students will automatically be preregistered for a 3-credit-hour Business Project.  In the fall, and until the 3rd quarter add/drop students can opt to withdraw from the course or select one project (but only one) from the three alternatives types of projects (see below). Bidding for places will not be required; procedures for qualification will be distributed at a later date. Special arrangements, to be approved by the course head, may be made for joint-degree students whose schedules do not allow them to participate in one of the three standard alternatives. Students with field-based project ideas that do not readily fit into one of the three standard project alternatives are encouraged to present such ideas to the course head, who will attempt to accommodate such projects within the course objectives authorized by the Faculty. The following sections provide general descriptions of the three alternatives choices in the Business Project family.  The details regarding such matters as application procedures, deadlines proposals, approvals, grading, and the potential to earn more than 3.0 credit hours.  See the web site:  https://intranet.darden.virginia.edu/dbp.

Fall: 895F (3.0 credit hours), Spring: 895S (3.0 credit hours), Qtr. 1: 8951 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 2: 8952 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 3: 8953 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 5: 8954 (1.5 credit hours) The objective of a Case Development Project is to describe a specific business problem clearly, succinctly and in a manner that fosters reflection, discussion and learning. The experience should challenge the student in the analysis and resolution of an unstructured managerial problem and offer an opportunity to work intensively with a member of the faculty. The product of a Case Development Project should normally be a case of a quality and focus suitable for inclusion in the MBA curriculum together with a written analysis and recommendation based exclusively on the information in the case.  To the extent possible, the case should revolve around a current situation and involve student interaction with the management of the participating organization.  A single student or a team of up to three students may undertake a Case Development Project. Depending on the workload agreed upon you may request 3.0 credit hours (120 working hours) or 1.5 credit hours (60 working hours).

In this course, you will play the role of a manager who has been hired by the CEO of a multinational company to explore and eventually exploit business opportunities in a Latin American country. You will have to choose a country in the region, prospect the market, decide on the entry strategy, value the opportunity, assess the risks, develop a detailed implementation plan, and provide a final recommendation to the CEO--and feel ready to personally jump into the country in order to start the operation. If there is an existing operation in a specific country, you will have to assess the risks and returns and be ready to talk with the local subsidiary manager to decide whether it makes sense to maintain the sub going or not.

For most of the twentieth century, Mexico was one of the most closed economies in the world. Since the mid-1980's, however, there has been a dramatic opening up of this potentially dynamic market of more than 90 million consumers (tenth largest country in the world, by population). Mexico has attracted foreign investment and created new business opportunities at a startling rate. As a result of economic, political and social changes (including NAFTA), accessing the Mexican market from the United States has become much easier. But the peso devaluation of December, 1994 and resulting depression have clearly demonstrated the need to better understand the complexities of doing business in Mexico, both in and of itself and as a gateway to the rest of Latin America. The purpose of this course is to enhance students' understanding of the Mexican business environment and the management of firms and business opportunities under these conditions. Designed from a general management perspective, it will touch on all aspects of the business environment, including finance, marketing, operations, people and economics. In addition, issues of cross-cultural management will be studied. This seminar will provide students with the opportunity to learn about Mexico from Mexican academicians, executives, and MBA students. The course will consist primarily of a five workday stay in Mexico City, on a schedule arranged by Darden’s partner school in Mexico, IPADE. (There will also be a weekend, most probably during the middle of the course, for cultural activities.) There will be some background reading and at least one evening introductory session (minimal preparation) prior to the trip (to be held in the late January/early February time frame, to avoid conflict with end-of-Quarter 3 activities). While in Mexico, students will interact intensively with IPADE MBA students in case-discussion classes (and learning teams) conducted at IPADE. Classes will be given by IPADE faculty (most classes will be in English, but some will be in Spanish with simultaneous translation, as a learning experience). There will also be briefings by some of Mexico’s top-performing companies and opportunities to meet and talk with some of Mexico’s leading executives.

Designed for prospective general managers to become familiar with the special challenges and opportunities of doing business in or with emerging economies. The emphasis will be in acquiring the analytical abilities to assess the strategic and operational issues relevant to general management in the fluctuating economic and political environment of emerging economies. Specific aspects to be stressed are the critical role of business-government relations, the choice of market entry alternatives, partnerships and alliances, privatization and restructuring in economies in transition, financial and investment decisions, organizational design, entrepreneurship, cross-cultural issues and the expatriate management career. The course highlights operational pitfalls in doing business in emerging economies. PRINICIPAL MODES OF INSTRUCTION: Cases; Outside Speakers with relevant practical experience.

During the last ten years we have seen a tremendous change in the economic structure of Europe. The European Union is a reality. Central Europe is emerging from forty years of Soviet domination. These changes heighten the need to understand opportunities and complexities of doing business in these markets. The purpose of this course is to enhance the student's understanding of the European business environment and the management of firms within it. The course will take a general management perspective and provide students with the opportunity to learn about Central Europe from leading academics, government officials and executives. The course will consist of a five workday stay in Europe. There will be some background reading and at least one evening session prior to the trip. While in Europe the students will engage in case-discussion classes, briefing sessions with top companies and have opportunities to meet and talk with experienced executives doing business in Central Europe.

The European Union (EU) is the world’s largest economic grouping and is planning further enlargement towards the East.  At the same time, it has set in train a programme of closer integration at both an economic and political level.  These developments will have far reaching implications not only for the economic and political environment of the EU but also for the global economy and in particular the United States.  The purpose of this course is primarily to provide students with an in-depth understanding of the economic driving forces behind EU integration.  However, such a course cannot overlook the political forces and consequences of closer integration.  A secondary purpose is to provide a framework for analyzing the consequences of closer economic union for Europe and its trading practices.

"Managing in Emerging Economies" is a three-week course with fifteen classes. The course is designed with the purpose to acquire the analytical capabilities and skills to manage in countries outside the triade with their distinctive business environments. The course covers typical strategic and operational issues facing companies and entrepreneurs, doing business in emerging economies and in economies in transition from a general management perspective. The prime objectives are: To develop foundation skills and competencies for a "global" perspective and vision To improve the understanding of the economic, social, political and cultural context of emerging economies and economies in transition in Asia, Middle and South America, Africa, Arabia and East Europe and to evaluate the impact of national development strategies on business. To explore the strategic alternatives of international firms with respect to emerging economies and to evaluate the results of globalization concepts To deal efficiently with the typical issues of managing in the distinctly different environment of developing countries and to develop guidelines to avoid operational pitfalls To create the awareness and skills to manage effectively in cross-cultural situations To assist participants to assess the opportunities and challenges of an international career in emerging economies. PRINICIPAL MODES OF INSTRUCTION: Cases; Guest Speakers; Group Assignments; Role Play Simulations

Most industries today are operating in a global competitive environment.  Even though many business organizations are not directly involved in international business transactions, they are, nevertheless, exposed to and affected by the competitive thrusts of international players.  Thus, unavoidable threats and substantial opportunities exist in the global marketplace.  Successful business managers in the future will need to have international competence.  Management of International Business (MIB) contributes to the development of management skills in this respect. MIB introduces students to the special aspects of operating in the global environment.  The course addresses fundamental concepts and tools that international business managers need to know as well as the need to develop awareness of and respect for other cultures.  Whether or not we agree with different customs and business practices, it is imperative that we understand them if we wish to conduct business in an international context.  In order to accomplish its objectives, a cross-functional approach is taken.  MIB addresses how differences in countries’ economic, political, cultural, and legal environment affect functional business decisions in the fields of strategy, finance, marketing, production, and organizational behavior.  The course does not typically address these fields separately but, instead, stresses integration within an international business context.  Besides covering diverse functional areas, the course also examines business issues within a variety of countries and geographic regions.  Business decisions take place in Africa, East, Southeast, and South Asia, Western and Eastern Europe, South America, and the United States.

Deregulation, privatization, and changes in existing regulations are key forces driving transformation in industries around the globe.  Deregulation and privatization have opened up a wide range of markets to competition of a fundamentally different nature.  Health care, telecommunications, electricity, airlines, banking, and financial services are among the most prominent of these rapidly evolving industries.  Even more dramatically, privatization has transformed entire economies in Asia, Eastern Europe, and the former Soviet Union. Many of these industries comprise most of what has come to be known as the “new economy,” and are characterized by structural conditions such as network externalities, poorly defined property rights, heavy investment in “knowledge capital,” rapid innovation, and intense research and development.  These conditions have important political, economic, and managerial implications that are redefining the relationships among business, government, and society at large. An important theme of the course will be that managers often have constituencies that extend beyond their customers, competitors, workers, and shareholders, and that they must respond to and manage these interest groups effectively to succeed in the modern economy. This course will examine the implications of these structural characteristics for the competitive process.  It will show how emerging technologies, exogenous events, changing societal values, and other environmental forces shape the markets in which we compete, and the institutions that define the nature of competition. It will develop an understanding of market failures due to natural monopolies and information asymmetries, and discuss how regulatory changes have altered the nature of competition in industries characterized by these conditions.  A major theme of the course is that these “failures,” and also attempts to correct them, give rise to significant opportunities.  In this regard, the course will show how strategy and tactics can be shaped, not only to react to these changes, but also to alter the evolution of regulatory institutions and practices, and thus gain competitive advantage. Examples of cases to be studied include changes in the nature of reimbursement in the health care industry, such as the move to “capitated” reimbursement, the move to incentive-based regulations in telecommunications, electricity, and elsewhere, the economics and politics of spectrum auctions in the U.S. and elsewhere, and the impact of environmental policies on competition in the chemical processing industry and elsewhere.

1.      To develop an understanding of risks in emerging markets, such as world market risks, country macroeconomic and political risks, country-level market risks, institutional and regulatory risks (such as capital control, financial market segmentation, and investment restrictions), and industry and project risks. 2.      To develop an understanding of how to identify, assess and mitigate risks in emerging markets; and how to allocate risks and returns to achieve greater efficiency (low-cost financing) and effectiveness (optimal behavior). 3.      To expand on the knowledge of CAPM and introduce alternative models on how the cost of capital is estimated in emerging markets.  Why do we need new frameworks for estimating the cost of capital?  What makes valuation in emerging markets different from that in the US?  How do we estimate the cost of capital that incorporates the time value of money and the risk premium commensurate with a particular emerging market investment? 4.      To construct and use DCF models for valuing assets in emerging markets.  In addition to using alternative approaches to estimating the discount rate for emerging market projects, we will also consider how currency risks and other risks should be handled in a DCF framework. 5.      To develop an understanding of the value of using real options in making investment decision in emerging markets. Given the high volatility in investment returns in emerging markets, real options are valuable and should be exploited to create value. This course builds on the knowledge and analytical skills that students have acquired from economics and finance courses, and from their work experience.  It assumes that students have taken Valuation in Financial Markets.  It is targeted for students who wish to pursue careers in investment banking, international finance and consulting.

The purpose of this course is to involve students in understanding the interaction of stakeholder groups in the resolution of conflict on issues of both public and private policy. It will focus on the governance issues in the relations between environmentalist organizations, government agencies, and private corporations in the search of balance in environmental management. Topics will be treated on a global level as much as possible. Projects will immerse students in a "live" environmental governance issue and will culminate in a mock rule-making exercise. While the course focuses on environmental governance, the lessons are generalizable to other questions of societal governance.

Today's complex environment favors managers who understand government processes, are politically aware, are mindful of the interaction between media and government and business, and appreciate how business can gain strategic advantage by monitoring and working with government at all levels. The purpose of this course is to prepare students to meet these managerial requirements, and to participate in complex decisions when changing laws, regulations, and other governmental factors have major long-term implications. In addition to case situations and readings on current issues, selected speakers from business and government will add their expertise.

GBUS 834 CULTURAL CONTEXT OF INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: EAST ASIA The primary objective of this course is to introduce the culture of China and East Asia to future managers of American multinational corporations. The course is designed to enable the novice to gain insight into the most salient features of Chinese culture as a local expression of East Asian culture. Course content reflects a view of culture with three distinguishing characteristics: (1) traditional ideas and their attached values; (2) patterns of behavior and action that justify or rationalize those patterns; and (3) institutions that are products of transmitted patterns of behavior and that shape future behavior. Students will be encouraged to analyze these features of culture in terms of their relevance to successful business behavior in China and the East Asian cultural world. A secondary objective of the course is to inspire in course participants a refined international perspective. As they are introduced to the unique features of the culture of China and East Asia, students will be encouraged to think in terms of a world comprising discrete national and cultural traditions, and to consider what that implies for American business interests abroad.

In this course, we are going to look at a set of powerful ideas related to economic growth, industrial and corporate organization and the dynamics of competition. Although the readings and topics might appear to be disparate, I believe that they are connected in a variety of ways. It is my goal to carry on a conversation with you through the semester that helps illuminate those connections. When we are done I believe that the material will represent an intellectually stimulating and challenging way to complete the MBA program. I have several thoughts about the course that I want to share with you. I hope that you take them seriously and then decide whether or not this course meets your needs. First, the choice of subjects and approaches is idiosyncratic; it represents things that I am interested in and is certainly not a typical course. Second, many of the readings are theoretical. They generally are versions that the authors have prepared for a non-technical audience but the articles are still rigorous, theoretical and challenging. Third, the discussions and assignments are open ended. Occasionally, we will reach a conclusion but for the most part the implications of the readings and cases will be ambiguous. There will be very little closure. Finally, these are topics that interest me but are at the edge of my expertise. I am learning as we go so you need to be comfortable working collaboratively. In fact, you should be more than comfortable, you should be committed to it.

The global economy has been affected in recent decades by powerful trends and powerful shocks.  The global financial system has evolved in response to the structural changes in the world economy, the risks associated with the shocks and the responses by policymakers.  This course is designed to provide an opportunity for students to gain the most up-to-date view of these forces available.  This will prepare them to assume responsibilities for operating in global markets immediately after graduation. The course will build upon the tools and perspectives developed in First Year BPE.  It will allow students to deepen their macroeconomic tools and translate them into a global investment perspective.  Students will develop their ability to translate policy changes into their impact on financial markets and to understand linkages between stock, bond  and currency markets.  Historical lessons from the evolution of the global financial system will be offered and comparisons will be made with the current global environment.  Comparative perspectives about investing in developed vs. emerging markets will be offered.  Extensive contemporary readings and speakers will be assigned.

Whether you are new to making presentations, an experienced presenter or simply terrified to even think about speaking to an audience, Speaking about Business will give you the strategies, tools and professional coaching to deliver any type of presentation with confidence. Speaking About Business explores in more depth the strategies of communication framed in FY Leadership Communication, in particular oral communication.  Professionals in all industries consistently rank oral communication as one of the key factors for success.  In fact, research shows that business practitioners believe it’s almost impossible to rise through the career ranks without polished presentations skills. Speaking about Business examines strategies to develop, deliver and analyze effective presentations.  We’ll look at giving informative presentations such as briefing employees on organizational changes or updating community members on fund raising goals.  Then we’ll study strategies of persuasion and how to frame and present messages that may be controversial or uncomfortable for an audience to hear.  These will include pitching a service or product and delivering bad news.  Finally, we will practice presenting as a team.  Throughout the course we will study practical strategies that support you in refining and polishing your presentation skills.

In spite of the saying, financial numbers rarely speak for themselves.  They also require context and stories to help people understand their origins, make sense of a given interpretation, and see the consequences for a company, market or stakeholders. Telling Financial Stories will help future consultants, bankers and general managers interpret financial data in a number of challenging settings in which strategic company and leadership objectives are on the line.  Students will learn frameworks for messaging to inform and influence, with topics ranging from reporting corporate earnings to pitching a startup. To advance students’ persuasive storytelling skills, the course will draw from various disciplines, including finance, marketing, ethics, accounting, and communication.  We will rely on cases, guest speakers, and a final project. Our speakers will represent varying perspectives from Fortune 500 companies to journalists. In the first days of the course, students will identify a company or analyst to follow as a quarter-long project, which culminates in a final deliverable in lieu of an exam.

When you are making decisions or building a strategy, convincing others to act or pitching and idea, data is vital. By transforming data into visualizations, you can present complex data sets in ways that your audience can better understand and that make a stronger impact. Effective data visualizations weave information and visual storytelling to create meaning from undifferentiated data and so provide insights that add business-relevant value. The ability to analyze a data set, find insights, and bring these insights into persuasive storytelling is critical to influencing audiences. This course introduces students to design principles for creating meaningful stories that stem from quantitative and qualitative data and facilitate leadership decision-making. The course exercises will include working with cases and case datasets, critiquing ineffective charts and re-creating them into persuasive data visualizations, and presentating visual stories in a variety of contexts. Students will have an opportunity to produce visual storyboards, nurturing their abilities to tell stories that stand alone and have logical progressions. Course data sets will be drawn from a variety of leadership, business, and technology subject areas. This course is meant to benefit students who seek to learn how to use data visualization tools, sharpen their abilities to design visual arguments, extract stories from data sets, and become better presenters.

Media and entertainment businesses represent a large part of the attention economy, not to mention the global economy and our social lives. Media and entertainment businesses sell art to consumers – stories, expressions, emotions, and experiences.  Yet these businesses are also driven by hard core business analytics and strategy. The course targets students interested in banking, consulting, and general management who will work in or serve clients in publicly traded media, entertainment, and tech firms. The course is designed to help students increase their media literacy, deepen their knowledge about media and entertainment industries, gain critical analytical skills specific to analyzing media data, and design media and business strategies for media and entertainment emerging business models and dynamic customer bases. Course exercises will include working with case samples, analyzing data sets to gain familiarity with industry challenges and needs, evaluating firm investment opportunities, as well as creating new media or entertainment products or services. Data sets will be drawn from a variety of sources, such as social media, television, advertising, video games, and Web 3.0/Metaverse.

curriculum.course: COM	8151: Writing for Impact and Influence
curriculum.description: In this course, students will be immersed in intimate, hands-on writing instruction focused on contemporary communication channels and tools most widely used in today’s workplace. The course will provide insights and techniques into drafting informative and inspiring team- and organization-wide email broadcasts, executive briefs, business and funding proposals, and strategic planning documents. Additionally, students will be exposed to best practices in creating internal and external web content, infographics and design elements, speeches, investor communication documents, and company mission statements. Students will work on crafting and enhancing their own professional “narratives and brands,” with guidance on using social media and other communication channels to position themselves as thoughtful, insightful and credible leaders.

LDSP 8341:  WOMEN, GENDER, & WORK: LEADERSHIP STORIES & CAREER NARRATIVES Gender norms (meaning our ideas of how men and women should act) shape our own desires, preferences, choices, and expectations. They shape our interpersonal interactions with employers, colleagues, partners, and friends, in terms of how we see ourselves, how we present ourselves, and how others receive us.  Gender norms shape the stories we tell ourselves about our own work, career, and professional success, as well as the larger narratives we hold about the ability, value, and experience of others.  Resulting from the social construct of gender norms, we each possess a sense of who we are as a man, woman, or nonbinary person, and choose how we want to communicate or express our gender identity to others. This course focuses on the ways that gender norms, gender identity, and gender expression affect one’s work, leadership, career, and professional success.  We take a multi-disciplinary approach that focuses on the experiences of female-identifying leaders while also acknowledging the limitations posed by gender binaries.  In our discussion of gender, we will analyze additional categories and identities such as race, class, ethnicity, and sexuality to better understand women’s and men’s experiences in a gendered workplace. Please note that while this course centers stories about women and narratives regarding gender, all students, regardless of gender identity, can benefit from the course in two ways.  First, students will gain greater awareness of the way that gender is embedded in all aspects of work, life, and society.  Second, students will learn important tools and skills that are crucial for all emerging leaders.  These include: honing your story for professional audiences; navigating the intersections of your identities and professional life; learning effective strategies to advocate for yourself at work and at home; leveraging your network for maximum gain; and aligning your personal values with your actions. The learning method of this course is mostly discussion based with some experiential activities; we strive to create a forum for open-ended, collaborative exchanges to further our own thinking, understanding, and problem solving.  A primary goal of the course is to use the stories of others to intentionally move forward in our own personal and professional journeys after Darden.  Each student will interview a Darden alumna, and the final paper will be a case based on your interview.

The objective of this course is to further develop management and leadership skills through a better understanding of ·       Personal and institutional means of managing conflict ·       The complementary dynamics of cooperation and competition in reaching sustainable multi-stakeholder agreements ·       The appropriate and balanced application of negotiation, mediation and arbitration alternatives ·       Approaches to managing cross-cultural impediments and opportunities ·       Ways in which conflict and consensus can be leveraged to promote good outcomes,  mutual understanding, creativity and personal growth While rooted in negotiation and conflict theory, this course will provide pragmatic and practical general management skills and should therefore be of interest to all students, regardless of their specific career or personal goals. Principal mode of instruction:  Cases, readings, extended simulations and in-class exercises. Suggested Prerequisite:  Negotiation (not required but preferred.)

Academic Course Description: The course builds on the observation that our intuition can differ substantially from the rational way one should go about interpreting information or making decisions. We will learn the most prevalent gaps between intuition and analysis. We will also introduce quantitative models to predict the perceived value of an alternative when using intuition, and compare it with its rational value. The primary goal is to improve the quality of one’s decisions by first gaining more self-awareness of how intuition works, and the mistakes it can produce. The secondary goal is to know how our colleagues and client’s reason at an intuitive level, and use this knowledge to improve one’s negotiations and marketing skills. The ideas discussed in the course apply to all business areas, including marketing, human resource management, entrepreneurship, and finance. The course combines qualitative and quantitative discussions, and its technical level is slightly above first year Decision Analysis.

This is a business-world-focused course on game theory: the mathematical modeling of strategic interaction among rational (and irrational) actors. Since its inception in the early twentieth century, game theory has become the cornerstone of economic theory, with 13 Nobel prizes going to game theorists. The theory applies not only to what we typically refer to as “games” in the common language (Chess, Poker, Go, Soccer, Mario Kart, etc.), but to any situation where consequences for individual actors depend on actions of both themselves and others. Some of the common applications covered in the course include competition between firms, trading in financial markets, auctions, international politics, warfare, and artificial intelligence. The course starts with the fundamentals of the theory (inc. Nash equilibrium, subgame perfection, Bayesian games) but then focuses more on applying the theory in a real-world context. The course is designed to be highly interactive, with most sessions including simulations and games to be played in class.

Machine learning and AI are increasingly becoming primary considerations for many business. These tools are at the core of many new disruptive, data-intensive business models. In this course, students will gain exposure to and practice with the concepts and tools in machine learning and modern artificial intelligence. The concepts and tools covered include programming, data visualization, cloud computing, and natural language processing. Through materials designed for the novice, students will be introduced to coding in Python and learn to develop cutting-edge predictive models from large datasets as well as programmatically use pre-trained models, such as so called foundation models, for inference tasks. Teams will compete to develop the most accurate forecasts for a particular application.

The complete course in project management will include Monte Carlo simulation for project risk analysis within project planning, scoping, and network analysis. The critical path method will be employed. Topics of resource allocation, project monitoring, and real options thinking will be included. Students will learn Microsoft Project, @Risk for Project, Basecamp, and other state-of-art software and be ready for planning and executing large-scale projects and utilizing agile methods. Students will also consider the challenge of managing projects as an entrepreneur and develop an awareness of behavioral decision-making biases that come to play in project planning.

In today’s competitive landscape, where efficiency and productivity are paramount for business success, the ability to navigate complex operational challenges is more critical than ever. The vast array of choices available in decision-making processes often exceeds the capacity of manual analysis, necessitating      the use of sophisticated optimization algorithms. These algorithms allow organizations to systematically identify optimal decisions that maximize specific objectives while adhering to various operational constraints. Using these techniques is now commonplace across diverse sectors, including logistics, pricing, cloud computing, online advertising, portfolio management, inventory control, and AI, underpinning many processes we rely on daily. In this course, we will explore what kind of business challenges can be effectively solved using optimization techniques. There will be a strong focus on practical application optimization techniques to business cases rather than a deep dive into optimization theory. Building on skills learned in Q1 DA, we will learn how to formulate and solve a variety of linear, discrete, non-linear, and stochastic optimization problems. We will introduce industry-standard software that will allow these problems to be solved at scale. There will be a focus on using data and AI to aid our formulations wherever possible.

While every year technology improvements make it cheaper and easier to build more powerful software, creating winning products and offerings is tougher than ever. By one measure, 64% of features are rarely or never used, 50-70% of IT projects fail, and 90% of new products are flop. That’s a lot of waste, expense, and missed opportunity. That’s a lot of waste, expense, and missed opportunity.

By the end of this class, you will have lost your fear of tinkering (with software). You’ll also have a hands-on understanding of how to translate software design inputs into working software. As an MBA considering roles like product manager, founder, or consultant, this is important. Between being a working software developer and knowing zero about coding, there’s a productive middle place. This is a place where you can: ·        participate in discussions about product/system development ·        engage confidently in meaningful learning about the software/system you’re managing

This course will introduce you to the modern practice of product management in digital. You’ll learn how product managers create product/market fit for new products and enhance it for existing products. You’ll also learn how generalist product managers establish successful interfaces with key functions like design, development/engineering, data science, sales/marketing and support/operations. This course will help students understand best current practices in the area and how to apply the in their role as product manager. Special attention will be paid to lessons learned in Silicon Valley and other innovation centers. Please Note: This class is organized around developing a managerial perspective. For a hands-on compliment to developing successful products, please see also ‘Software Design’.

iteratively testing propositions and design for user value. The course experience is anchored in active learning on the topics above by way of a student or industry sponsored project. The focus of the student experience is on directed practice which deepens and integrates their foundation understanding of product design, application development, and analytics/AI. Enrolled students should have or acquire a foundation understanding of the concepts above. If you’ve taken: Software Design (GBUS 8632), Data Science in Business (8496) or Data Visualization and Analytics (GBUS 7600), and Coding with GPT (8633), then you already have the necessary preparation. If you haven’t you can fulfill the prerequisites with prior industry experience or online course equivalents. Please contact the instructor (Alex Cowan- cowana@darden.virginia.edu) to review specific alternatives. Individual teams will schedule biweekly meetings where instructor will discuss a team’s deliverables and next steps after each block. Following blocks three, five, and seven, the instructors and all teams will meet together to present results and discuss the quality of their work and its implication for next steps. The focus of this class is shifted toward out-of-class work, relative to in-class time. The reason for this is that the students have already achieved working fluency in the relevant topics and the goals of this class are to achieve integrated practice. Because this practice is directed by the course, the course will accelerate their practical learning. 1. Team Projects-The courses deliverables are anchored in team projects. 2. Industry Readings-Students will review key posts and book chapters for perspective on current practice. 3. Supporting Web Tutorials-Students will encounter a few new topics, incremental to their foundation understanding of application, design, application development, and data science. These will be offered by way of existing course videos (via Coursera courses), third party tutorials, and sample deliverables.

In this course, students can master the process of adapting technology to the needs of the market and developing an actionable strategy. Students will learn the integrative skills necessary to do a startup even if they are not prepared to commit to the Incubator. The course will also allow students who are interested in becoming entrepreneurs after graduation but are not yet committed to an idea to identify attractive opportunities and explore the possibility of undertaking a startup. Students are given the opportunity to experience firsthand the process of finding and validating a market need, to search for optimal/implementable technology solutions, to assess the possible funding strategies and to develop an implementation plan. Students from Darden and potentially those from other UVA schools will come together to identify market needs, find technologies (in the broad sense of the term and not just IT) appropriate to address those needs, and develop a business plan. The course will develop in four phases: identify market need, identify technologies that can be applied to address those needs, prioritize which combination of needs and technologies are most implementable and quickest to market, and develop a business plan with emphasis on identifying next steps and the critical path to commercialization.

Fall: 895F (3.0 credit hours), Spring: 895S (3.0 credit hours), Qtr. 1: 8951 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 2: 8952 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 3: 8953 (1.5 credit hours), Qtr. 5: 8954 (1.5 credit hours) The objective of a Case Development Project is to describe a specific business problem clearly, succinctly and in a manner that fosters reflection, discussion and learning. The experience should challenge the student in the analysis and resolution of an unstructured managerial problem and offer an opportunity to work intensively with a member of the faculty. The product of a Case Development Project should normally be a case of a quality and focus suitable for inclusion in the MBA curriculum together with a written analysis and recommendation based exclusively on the information in the case.  To the extent possible, the case should revolve around a current situation and involve student interaction with the management of the participating organization.  A single student or a team of up to three students may undertake a Case Development Project. Depending on the workload agreed upon you may request 3.0 credit hours (120 working hours) or 1.5 credit hours (60 working hours).

This course is intended to provide students with an opportunity to work closely with a faculty adviser to produce a case study of a real business situation. Students may already have a case setting in mind or may call upon their faculty supervisor for an introduction to the setting for a case. After the identification of a cooperating business or not-for-profit organization, students conduct field interviews with executives of the subject organization to understand the issues to be addressed in the case study. Students then prepare a draft of the case giving special attention to identifying the principal issue or issues to be included and submit the draft to the sponsoring organization, which certifies the accuracy of the facts in the case. Students are encouraged to prepare case studies that require significant decisions as they are more effective classroom instruments and challenge students to define carefully the prevalent issues, consider all possible alternative actions, and then recommend a plan of action for the company’s management. After receiving approval of the cases facts from the sponsoring organization, students will prepare an analysis of the case, carefully noting the issues, alternatives, and a recommended plan of action.

This course is intended to provide students with an opportunity to work closely with a faculty adviser to produce a case study of a real business situation. Students may already have a case setting in mind or may call upon their faculty supervisor for an introduction to the setting for a case. After the identification of a cooperating business or not-for-profit organization, students conduct field interviews with executives of the subject organization to understand the issues to be addressed in the case study. Students then prepare a draft of the case giving special attention to identifying the principal issue or issues to be included and submit the draft to the sponsoring organization, which certifies the accuracy of the facts in the case. Students are encouraged to prepare case studies that require significant decisions as they are more effective classroom instruments and challenge students to define carefully the prevalent issues, consider all possible alternative actions, and then recommend a plan of action for the company’s management. After receiving approval of the cases facts from the sponsoring organization, students will prepare an analysis of the case, carefully noting the issues, alternatives, and a recommended plan of action.

This elective course brings to life the American Civil War through readings and sessions with Gary Gallagher, world-renowned American Civil War historian, and an intensive two-day visit to the site of the Battle of Gettysburg. While visiting the battlefield, students will examine how Union army and Confederate army commanders faced their moments of decision. In small group settings and using the case method approach, faculty and staff will challenge participants to make and defend their own battlefield decisions and consider the relevance of these judgments for professional growth and development of a personal leadership style. Participants will also be challenged both on the battlefield and in a final reflective paper to consider what they learned from the experience and how it relates to today’s business culture, business opportunity, and corporate challenges and to reflect personally on the impacts of the program on personal decision making, communication style, and leadership approach.

Course Overview: This is a class teaches and applies sound fundamentals of entrepreneurship for those testing or building a FT venture or side gig. The cadence is two-week sprints alternating customized milestones and common deliverable tools to build your venture. Students in this class will be doing things to build their business. We frequently draw on Effectuation and Village Capital operating systems. No guest speakers or lectures. Guest mentors commonly join to give feedback. These will largely include founders and investors. Classes are Monday 430-615p. Full semester, 3 credits, taught Fall and Spring. Substantial work outside class expected. Beyond teaching this class as an adjunct, I’m an entrepreneur, angel investor, and advisor to startups. I also mentor at TechStars and the iLab and have been an EIR at Wharton and guest mentor at Village Capital. I love early stage and fast-growing startups and the innovative, resourceful, and tenacious founders that drive them. You can easily find my bio CrunchBase or LinkedIn. Syllabus available by request or day #1. Course Objectives: Our mission is to work together to fight through the start-up jungle, navigating around trouble where possible, and fighting through it when foresight fails so you gain applied mastery over skills that will drive your future success as a founder or investor in other ventures regardless how this one fares. If you are putting in the time and effort, I will be generous with my time, ideas, and network to support your venture. If you want to win contests I will support. VV teams tend to do well w 60% of 2018 Ecup finalists, 2017 winner, and 2018 ACC Inventure winners from VV. Some raise money while in class; those with revenue are challenged to grow at least 20%/month; and many are much earlier seeking MVP or PMF which makes it all fun. Elements of Grade: If you care more about your grade than your venture, VV probably is not for you. But if you care about your venture and are coachable your grade will be fine. ·        Class Contribution: 15%.

8509   Tactical Topics for Entrepreneurship Through Acquisition This course provides students with exposure to practical matters faced by operators of smaller enterprises. Whether starting or acquiring a small enterprise, entrepreneurs will be better prepared having been introduced to real-world topics such as relationships with key service vendors (banking, legal, accounting), commercial leasing terms, employee benefit programs, state and local public policy, government procurement, commercial insurance, commercial security interests, credit policies, and financial and operational control systems– from the vantage of the smaller enterprise where choices are often limited as compared to the options available to larger enterprises.

GBUS 8634 Interviewing Experiential Field-Based Elective (Part 1) This course is an opportunity for students to learn effective interviewing, talent evaluation, verbal and written communication, marketing skills, and leadership skills. In addition, the course teaches students to interact with a diverse group of people and gain insights into their potential through active listening.  In the workplace, our graduates will be asked to interview and hire people, conduct performance evaluations, and present their ideas and perspective in compelling ways. Learning to interview and assess potential will provide students the opportunity to strengthen their leadership, communication, and management skills.

GBUS 8635 Interviewing Experiential Field-Based Elective (Part 2) This course is a continuation of the Q2 course and provides an opportunity for students to further master interviewing, talent evaluation, verbal and written communication, marketing skills, and leadership skills. In addition, the course allows the students to deliver a meaningful and relevant recommendation to aid in the work of the Admissions Office.
